title: 113_s743
content: The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes the collection of sales and use taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" authorizes Member States under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. Non-Member States can also enforce tax collection on sellers not qualifying for exceptions. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows states to require small sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales if they meet certain simplification requirements. This authority can only begin at least 6 months after the state enacts legislation specifying the taxes to which it applies and implements minimum simplification requirements. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" allows states to require remote sellers to file a single sales and use tax return with a single entity responsible for tax administration. States cannot impose more frequent filing requirements on remote sellers than nonremote sellers or impose additional collection requirements. Local jurisdictions cannot require remote sellers to submit tax returns or collect sales taxes. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates uniform sales and use tax base, sourcing of remote sales, and provision of tax information and software for remote sellers. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates certification procedures for software providers to calculate and file sales and use taxes in all qualified States. It relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for errors in tax collection, remittance, or noncollection caused by certified software providers or misleading information. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates certification procedures for software providers to calculate and file sales and use taxes in all qualified States. It relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for errors in tax collection, remittance, or noncollection caused by certified software providers or misleading information. Remote sellers and certified software providers are also provided with a 90-day notice of rate changes by the State or locality to update their information accordingly and avoid liability for collecting taxes at the previous rate during the notice period if the required notice is not provided. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" mandates certification procedures for software providers to calculate and file sales and use taxes in all qualified States. A State can require a remote seller to collect sales and use taxes only if their gross annual receipts in total remote sales exceed $1,000,000 in the previous year. Gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons or those with ownership relationships designed to avoid tax rules may be aggregated to meet the threshold. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" sets limitations on remote sellers collecting sales and use taxes based on their gross annual receipts exceeding $1,000,000 in total remote sales from related persons or those with ownership relationships designed to avoid tax rules. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" limits taxes to sales and use taxes only, does not affect nexus standards, allows remote sellers to choose software providers, and does not impact state licensing or regulatory requirements. The "Marketplace Fairness Act of 2013" limits taxes to sales and use taxes only, does not affect nexus standards, allows remote sellers to choose software providers, and does not impact state licensing or regulatory requirements. The Act also specifies that no new taxes should be imposed by states on products or services not previously taxed, applies only to remote sales, and does not affect intrastate sales or the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. In this Act, definitions include terms like "certified software provider" for tax compliance, "locality" referring to political subdivisions, "Member State" under the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement, "person" encompassing various legal entities, and "remote sale" as a sale conducted remotely. The curr_chunk defines terms related to remote sales, including "remote sale" as a sale into a State where the seller is not required to pay sales taxes, "remote seller" as a person making remote sales, and "sourced" as the location where the product is received by the purchaser. The curr_chunk explains that if an address is unknown for a remote sale, it is sourced to the seller's address. States granted authority must comply with the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The term "State" includes various territories and tribal organizations. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement is a multi-state agreement adopted in 2002. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. SEC. 6. PREEMPTION. This Act does not limit any powers of State or local jurisdictions unless specified.
